urn:contentItem:5XRH-14F1-F03R-N52S-00000-00Evil is Baked into Big Tech's Business Plan. Now What?2019-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:37ZLexisNexisEvil is Baked into Big Tech's Business Plan. Now What?Yves Smith

Dec 14, 2019( Naked Capitalism: http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Yves here. A supposedly staid organization like INET is broadcasting that rule by our new tech overlords is less than benign. Quite a change in their image in a fairly short time. By Lynn Parramore, Senior Research Analyst at the Institute for New Economic Thinking.

Originally published at the Institute for New Economic Thinking website[1] Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin famously launched their search engine with the mantra: 'Don't Be Evil.' Yet soon enough, their ambitions would lead them to talk publicly about doing good while stealthily refining business models based on exploiting, deceiving, and spying on their fellow humans. Maybe they harbored an adolescent notion of being good. As if nice intentions were enough - like their early aim to steer clear of ad-based business models — without the responsibility, wisdom, and judgment that guide them to reality. Or maybe they had soaked up too much of the Ayn Rand-ethos of the '80s. In any case, Page and Brin tossed their youthful idealism overboard to make superyacht-loads of money grabbing your personal data to sell to the highest advertising bidder. Together with other once-idealistic Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, they created gigantic, Gilded Age-style companies that can bully or buy off anyone who stands in their way, sucking up public resources and shredding the democratic fabric as they go. Page and Brin, who recently stepped down[2] from Google, are now the sixth and seventh richest people in the world. Amid a rising public outcry against Big Tech's alarming surveillance practices, monopolistic business practices, and growing threats to democracy, America needs guidance on how to reign in these behemoths. Enter the clear-eyed Financial Times columnist Rana Foroohar, who investigates how we ended up in this mess and proposes some practical ways to get back on track. In the following conversation, she discusses her penetrating new book, Don't be Evil: How Big Tech Betrayed Its Founding Principles — and All of Us[3], with the Institute for New Economic Thinking. Lynn Parramore: As global business correspondent, you write on a wide array of topics for the Financial Times. Why a book-length dive on this particular subject at this moment? Rana Foroohar: Two things. First, I was trolling for some focus in terms of where to throw my reporting energy, and I came across an amazing McKinsey Global Institute stat showing that 80 percent of corporate value was being held by just 10 percent of firms - those with the most IP [networking software] and data. Most were big tech companies, like the FAANGs[4] [Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, and Google]. At the same time, I came home one day and opened a credit card bill and started scrolling down it and noticed all these tiny charges in increments of $1.99, 3 bucks, etc. I noticed they were all from the App store. At first, I thought I'd been hacked, but it turns out that my 10-year-old son had become addicted to an online soccer game and racked up all these charges in 'in app' purchases. I was horrified as a mother, but fascinated as a journalist, and felt I needed to learn all about this insidious business model. LP: You mention that Silicon Valley was heavily influenced by 60s counterculture and that many people involved in its rise started out wanting world a better place for everyone. How did the tune go from 'We are the World' to 'Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap'? RF: I think that over the decades, the 'connect the world' ethos morphed from something beautiful into something that was really just about supra-national companies offshoring capital, data, and profits to wherever they could. Many of the people running the platform tech firms today are very young; they came of age in the 80s when you had a neoliberal ethos, a greed is good culture, and a sense that the only thing that the government can do is cut taxes. They don't think about the largest public/private ecosystem, or citizens - only consumers. That's a larger shift in the economy and society of course, but Big Tech represents it's apex - if capital can fly 35,000 feet over the problems of the nation state, data has been able go even further and faster. LP: We're used to throwing around the word 'big' in association with certain industries: Big Ag, Big Pharma, etc. But the bigness of Big Tech feels like something new. You mention, for example, that the market capitalizations of the FAANG companies is bigger than the economy of France. What does this bigness mean to the rest of the economy? RF: Platform companies enjoy a super-star effect to the nth degree. Their model has been to move fast, break things, ring fence as much data as possible and then use that position to establish monopoly power. That was always the aim, and the possibility with such firms - you can go back to economists like Hal Varian[5] and look at their early writings and see that data economists understood that potential. So, that's one reason that I don't buy it when tech titans come to Capitol Hill to testify and say 'oh, we had no idea.' Of course you did. That was the plan - to become the operating system for people's lives, in every aspect of their lives. LP: The issues surrounding Big Tech are incredibly complex. What is something you learned while writing this book that you might not have been aware of or fully understood before? RF: Per my point above, one thing that really amazed me was reading the first academic paper on search that Larry Page and Sergei Brin did while they were grad students at Stanford. It has a section in the appendix that admits that if you try to monetize a search engine via targeted advertising, as Google today does, you'll likely end up in a position where the interests of the users and the advertisers aren't in alignment. Which is, of course, exactly where we are today. In the beginning, the pair considered targeted advertising 'evil,' but as they got closer to IPO (and folks like former chair and CEO Eric Schmidt came into the picture) they loosened those principles. LP: How might we realign the interests of tech firms and interests of customers and citizens? Where do you stand on breaking these companies up v. regulating them more effectively? RF: I would like to see 4 things - first, public data banks in which democratically elected governments can decide which companies and which parts of the public sector get access to consider data and under what terms (rather like what Toronto is doing with the Google Sidewalk project). Data being considered a resource of value, like labor, with an appropriate portion of the corporate value extracted from it going back to the individual (this might be done via a sovereign wealth fund for data, or a digital dividend program - both are being considered in California). I think network and commerce should be separated, a la the 19th century railroad model or bank holding company model - a firm like Amazon, for example, shouldn't be able to own the entire ecommerce network, and compete against its own clients in commerce (particularly with no algorithmic transparency). And finally, we need a digital bill of rights that enshrines basic civil liberties in the digital space, and an FDA of technology to study the cognitive effects and regulate digital tech properly.https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2019/12/evil-is-baked-into-big-techs-business-plan-now-what.html?utm_source=feedburner..._medium=feed..._campaign=Feed:+NakedCapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29# This entry was posted in Banana republic[6], Free markets and their discontents[7], Guest Post[8], Legal[9], Regulations and regulators[10], Social policy[11], Surveillance state[12], Technology and innovation[13], The dismal science[14] on December 14, 2019[15] by Yves Smith[16]. urn:contentItem:5X6X-JJK1-F12F-F2K2-00000-00Evolution of business models in the era of privacy by design2019-10-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:37ZLexisNexisEvolution of business models in the era of privacy by designNew Delhi

New Delhi, Oct. 6 -- The right to privacy became a talking point in India two years ago when the Supreme Court upheld the overall validity of Aadhaar while disallowing its mandatory linking to services other than government benefits or subsidies. Last year, a committee headed by Justice B.N. Srikrishna proposed a data protection bill, which is still under consultation with multiple stakeholders.

As hundreds of millions of Indians come online with budget smartphones and the world's lowest mobile data rates, Prime Minister Narendra Modi referred to data as the "new gold" at the recent Howdy Modi event in Houston. US President Donald Trump, on his part, hailed Indian Americans for helping revolutionize technology to improve lives around the world.

And Google CEO Sundar Pichai pitched in by acknowledging concerns over privacy while pointing out the need to balance that with the benefits of a shared internet.

The big question is, 'Whose data is it, anyway?' What if tech companies were forced to compensate customers for using their data to derive profits?

Entrepreneurs and investors are thinking of new paradigms beyond government regulation.

Tim Berners-Lee, for example, wants to restore the original intent of his creation-the World Wide Web, which he feels big tech companies have taken over. His startup Inrupt is creating virtual personal online data stores (PODs) where users can "create, manage and secure" their data. They can then trade their data for services.PRIVACY 3.0

In India, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has created a new entity called "account aggregator", backed by technocrat Nandan Nilekani who was also behind Aadhaar and UPI. Approved account aggregators will act as intermediaries between companies seeking customer data and institutions like banks that can provide the data.

Aggregators will take consent of customers on what data can be shared for how long and for what purpose. The framework will make it easier for customers and small businesses to access their financial data from multiple sources for things like access to credit.

Currently, although tech companies routinely take a user's consent to access their data-such as identity or location, before providing a product or service, it's so convoluted that most people have to acquiesce blindly. Companies harvest all the data they can and use it in ways that customers can't even imagine. New frameworks aim to hand control back to users.

Entrepreneurs and investors are also thinking of ways in which privacy can evolve from just ticking the boxes for compliance.

"Privacy 2.0 should focus on trust," says Govind Shivkumar, principal at Omidyar Network India. "If consumers begin to trust some players more than others, companies will want that as a differentiating factor and competitive advantage."

This would make privacy a strategic priority instead of a compliance headache.

The trust-based framework would eventually evolve into Privacy 3.0 where it would be embedded into businesses.

An Omidyar Network India and Monitor Deloitte India paper that Shivkumar helped prepare sees the emergence of new business models, including personal data stores like Tim Berners-Lee envisages, tools for users to manage their preferences, and so on.

There would also be new B2B (business-to-business) models such as privacy services for enterprises, some of which could be artificial intelligence-led. Privacy certification agencies would come up to close the loop.

"We're looking at investment opportunities in startups across all three levels of privacy, from compliance to trust and Privacy 3.0 models," says Shivkumar.

"Our notion of privacy is rooted in individuals' control over what they share and how they manage their lives on digital platforms," adds Sushant Kumar of Omidyar Network India, who works on "responsible tech investments."AI WORLD

What complicates it is that technologies are fast-evolving, especially with the application of AI in virtually every sphere. "Technology should be publicly managed," says Anupam Guha, assistant professor at Centre for Policy Studies, IIT Bombay. "But it can't be a simplistic state-controlled thing because you can't trust the state."

His view is that public or community-led models, which are pro-people rather than pro-corporate or pro-state, can form. "If you want to forestall the problems we're seeing with monopolies, privacy or job losses from automation, you can choose to incentivise models that produce better results for the common man."

Proclaiming that data is the "new oil" or "new gold" suggests wealth creation. The question is for whom wealth is being created. Public discourse is veering towards a consumer-centric view.

Clark NJ: XBRL International has issued the following press release:

Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank (ECB), recently made a speech on the upheaval fintech is causing to the lending and payments system.

Financial technology uptake has been accelerating fast, with new technologies giving entrants better and cheaper ways to compete for core banking business. Regulation like the Payments Services Directive (PSD2) has fostered competition and innovation by opening up bank account information and enabling cheap, instant, cross border payments. While fintech firms could make the financial system more diverse and competitive, they also present new risks – especially as they move from payments into core banking services like credit.

Mersch outlines two scenarios: first, banks could rise to the digital challenge and upgrade their technological systems to compete with products offered by fintechs, retaining their customers and remaining under existing regulation. Alternatively, if banks fail to provide digital services, fast-moving fintechs and big tech firms could dominate the market, with banking services moving to less-regulated parts of the financial system.

Of course, the reality is likely to be much more complicated than these predictions. Regardless of what happens in the future, it’s essential that developments are closely monitored and regulation regularly adjusted accordingly.

Read the full speech, made at the 3rdAnnual Conference on Fintech and Digital Innovation, Brussels, on 26 February, here.

urn:contentItem:5PWD-9XS1-JDPT-T2NP-00000-00EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING GLOBAL ECONOMICS2017-11-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:37ZLexisNexisEWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING GLOBAL ECONOMICS

November 3, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER,

CEHIC: I'm delighted to say the ECB governing council member and Austrian National Bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, joins us. And also with us is Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer co-CIO.

Mr. Nowotny, so delighted to have you with us on set. Thank you for joining us. So my first question to you is, should the ECB be downsizing more quickly, given the state of the Eurozone economy, even though inflation is still below target?

NOWOTNY: Well, we have just made a decision last week.

CEHIC: You have? Was it the right one?

NOWOTNY: Yes, I think it is the right one. And we are having the volume we are buying starting this January of next -- next year for nine months. This reflects that we see that the economy is improving substantially. But we're not yet there where we want to be.

CEHIC: So you're not yet there, but do you think that there should be a more clear end date set for the stimulus or you think it's better to keep that open-ended at this point?

NOWOTNY: Frankly speaking, there had been a discussion about -- about this. There was a clear majority few that one should be flexible, which doesn't mean in my view that we have to go on forever. I think at some time, there will be, of course, reducing and then some kind of -- of an end date. But it's too early now to have this discussion.

CEHIC: But the issue of scarcity is a big one there, do you see any risk of scarcity in the bonds that you're buying?

NOWOTNY: Not really because we are buying quite a strong variety of -- of bonds, not only government bonds, also from the private -- from the private sector. We -- we -- we look the risk directly at this. So we are aware that this something that we have to be careful. But we have seen and -- in fact, we have had this discussion quite many times before (inaudible) I have nothing to buy any longer. We managed to do this. And I'm pretty sure at this lower -- at this lower volume that we have decided. We will be able to fulfil our task.

CEHIC: With reinvestment as well, do you see this as in some way upsetting the downsizing of stimulus? Or at least sort of moderating it somewhat?

NOWOTNY: We have declared last week that we have two aspects that are important, the one is the flows, this -- this what they're buying, but increasingly, it is also the stock. So that means we have, of course, quite a strong and increasing stock. And we have decided that we will reinvest these bonds when they become due. So this does have an (inaudible) effect on the markets.

CEHIC: How much could those reinvestments be? Could you put a number on it?

NOWOTNY: We will give numbers, but it's too early to tell now.

CEHIC: In your view, do you have any estimation of -- of -- of what you personally

NOWOTNY: It is, it is. It will be quite a substantial number.

CEHIC: Now, I did mention inflation earlier, the fact that it continues to disappoint. And this, of course, is the key thing that the ECB is targeting. This is a problem facing central bankers globally, but specifically in the Eurozone, why do you think we're not seeing inflation picking up?

NOWOTNY: Well, in fact, one has to be quite honest. For next -- for next year, for 2018, our forecasts are that we have even a lower inflation rate than we have 2017. This is mainly due to effects from the energy policy side. Our core inflation, that means inflation without energy, is going up. And here we have kind of a steady development towards high inflation rate in the -- in the range that we want to achieve. So I think we -- we are moving in the right direction. But we have to observe these things going on next year.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, the ECB as a whole doesn't see inflation returning to target before the end of 2019, when do you see it getting to that target, and what's going to drive it?

NOWOTNY: I think that inflation rates in 2018 might be higher than anticipated now because what we see is that energy prices are moving up. So this is one element with regards to core inflation. For core inflation, the most important element are wage developments. Here we have had, not only in Europe but also in the U.S., a rather strange development that it takes a long time for wages to react to the lower unemployment. So this is the famous Phillips curve conundrum that -- that we have. But I think this is just a matter of lags. So after some time, wages will keep up. If we look at the developments just for instance in Germany, where we have just now wage negotiations wages that are quite substantial (inaudible), we will have the same also in my country in Austria.

So I think with -- I'm not sure that these are really, let's say, structural changes, that it might just mean that it takes longer for wages to react to lower unemployment.

CEHIC: OK. So you do see that wage growth coming at some point, but we do hear this from a lot of people that it's coming, that it's coming, but then we're not there yet. So I'm wondering, is the ECB's mandate sits a purpose? Because there's been a lot of discussion about whether that inflation target, not just for the ECB but in general with central banks should actually be modified somewhat.

NOWOTNY: I think central banks should be very, very cautious in modifying their targets. This is also a matter of long-term credibility. On the other hand, we should not reduce this to say it has to be exactly 1.9. So we said from the start on that one has to see this as a medium-term perspective. So I think the most important element is to see what is the direction. And I think the direction is going the right way.

KEENE: Well, Mr. Nowotny, visiting our London studios here to meet with Bloomberg News, we're thrilled that he's with us today on "Bloomberg Surveillance." Yves Bonzon with us with Julius Baer. We will continue our discussion, and I really want to talk about the challenges of investment going forward into 2018.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer CIO, is still with us. Yves, we're seeing sterling steady today after the drop yesterday, that dovish hike from the BOE. Just very simply, where do you see the rate hike path going in 2018? The market pushed back its expectations after the decision in the press conference from Mark Carney.

BONZON: I think there was a clear desire by the central banks to reassure everyone that this is not the beginning of a hard and fast, I think, campaign. The central bank is struggling to explain the wage puzzle, absence of wage growth despite of significant tightening of the labor market. And there's so much uncertainty going on in this country with the Brexit negotiation process being still quite unclear. I think it's prudent for the central banks to actually kind of reload the monetary gun, meaning, by hiking interest rates a little bit, they are making room for accommodation, losing -- if needed, down the road, if eventually worse comes to worst with regards to the Brexit impact.

CEHIC: Yes. And speaking of Brexit, you know, one way that could have interpreted that press conference was that the Bank of England was really tying its forward guidance to Brexit in a way, but of course, that's one of the most uncertain things here. So is there any point in the forward guidance?

BONZON: Well, I guess, they are very pragmatic, you know. I think they are very concerned about communicating well and not surprising investors. And I think it's fair to mention that Brexit is an important unknown, non-unknown but unknown.

CEHIC: Yes. But going back to the wage puzzle then, so one thing that people have said to me is, look, this is about supply side deterioration, and that's where we might eventually get that upward pressure on wages, the Bank of England has used that argument as well itself. Not everyone is convinced by that, though, are you?

BONZON: I'm not actually because I think we have an absence of wage pressure across the skill set spectrum, you know, from low skill and medium skill to even higher skill labor. It's a combination of several things. Technology trends, you know, replacing labor, and sometime labor of the quite skilled kind with automated processes. In -- in the meantime, at the lower end of the skill spectrum, if you think about industry like retailing, these companies are so -- under so much margin pressure, they don't have much room to increase wages actually. So I think the pricing power on the labor side in spite of a relatively tight labor market, is not that great.

Furthermore, I understand social benefit access have been tightened in the U.K., so the -- the relative competition of social benefits, as opposed to low wages, you know, is also (inaudible). So there are so many factor at work, including the gig economy. It's very hard to predict what will happen with wage growth.

KEENE: Yves, I want to go to one of the things of the week that maybe was (inaudible) under the economics, finance, and investment that we do. And that was a remarkable idea of the tech troops showing up at -- in Washington, putting their hands up and testifying and all that. In the summary of -- of this was the power of the European Union to maybe rein in American tech might. I mean, I thought there was a real sea change here. How does it look the prism of Julius Baer as the E.U. tries to regulate the new technology we're all dealing with? Is that a good thing, and will -- will it increase, will Brussels' effort increase in the coming years?

BONZON: There's a very clear and a strong desire by the European Union to intervene in these sectors, on these big tech platforms. They're divided in two group in the world today. You have basically China, which has ringfenced its market and allowed for the development of local giants, and you have the American giants that have invaded the world ex-China. One of the problems, of course, is also in a globalized world the taxation of corporate profits. There seems to be a growing effort in the European Union to find a way to tax these tech platforms. So I think the pressure, the regulatory pressure on them will keep on increasing, but it's a slow process. You see in the European Union, they are struggling to agree because some countries actually benefit from these companies. So it's a -- it's a very long process, I think, but definitely pressure is mounting.

KEENE: But this is really fascinating, folks, and particularly the idea of a European model of entrepreneurship and technology versus an Anglo-American model. Which will win out, Yves, five years out?

BONZON: It's hard to say on the five-year ...

KEENE: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

BONZON: ... on a five-year view who's going to win that, so ...

KEENE: It's Friday.

BONZON: That -- that the -- the U.S. technology platform has such a head start to begin with. When you account for the networking effect, you know, the amount of users that they have managed to gather, give them a head start that which will be hard to overcome. So I think most -- most likely, the -- the main risk for them is regulatory action also on the U.S. side. We have all these discussions with regards to what happened during the election. So again, there -- there -- there is mounting pressure. But on the other end, this is a very strategic industry the United States. And I don't want -- I don't think they want to damage their chances.

CEHIC: Yves, I want to ask you about another piece of regulation, which is PSD2. We talked a lot about MiFID II, but one thing about PSD2 and Europe is that some people are saying, you know, it really could pit European banks against FinTech rivals because of the data issue. And then if we look more globally, you know, there's a lot of talk about whether Amazon could be a challenger for big banks either in the U.S. or globally. How much of a risk are banks in Europe and the U.S. from FinTech rivals because of regulation in Europe? And are they at -- they at more risk than their U.S. rivals?

BONZON: Yes. The extent to which Fintech will compete with traditional finance models is suddenly strongly influenced by regulatory trends and decisions. No question. By the way, one of the problem in Europe is you don't have a (inaudible) regulation across the 27 countries, you know. And that makes the development of start up in Europe far more difficult than it is in the U.S. Now, at the end of the day, finance is about managing a balance sheet, you know, it's balance sheet business. There's a systemic risk involved. So yes, I think there will be venture into the financial industry from FinTech startup. I think still the winners are most likely going to be those of the legacy business model that adapt and leverage on FinTech breakthrough.

CEHIC: Yes. So is it more about then adapting rather than try to find loopholes in the regulation?

BONZON: Absolutely. Yes.

CEHIC: Thank you so much. Yves Bonzon of Julius Baer, where he is a CIO, great to have you with us.

KEENE: Yes, thank you so much, Mr. Bonzon, for joining us on this Friday.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

NOVEMBER 3, 2017

SPEAKERS: EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm delighted to say the ECB governing council member and Austrian National Bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, joins us. And also with us is Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer co-CIO.

Mr. Nowotny, so delighted to have you with us on set. Thank you for joining us. So my first question to you is, should the ECB be downsizing more quickly, given the state of the Eurozone economy, even though inflation is still below target?

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK: Well, we have just made a decision last week.

CEHIC: You have? Was it the right one?

NOWOTNY: Yes, I think it is the right one. And we are having the volume we are buying starting this January of next -- next year for nine months. This reflects that we see that the economy is improving substantially. But we're not yet there where we want to be.

CEHIC: So you're not yet there, but do you think that there should be a more clear end date set for the stimulus or you think it's better to keep that open-ended at this point?

NOWOTNY: Frankly speaking, there had been a discussion about -- about this. There was a clear majority few that one should be flexible, which doesn't mean in my view that we have to go on forever. I think at some time, there will be, of course, reducing and then some kind of -- of an end date. But it's too early now to have this discussion.

CEHIC: But the issue of scarcity is a big one there, do you see any risk of scarcity in the bonds that you're buying?

NOWOTNY: Not really because we are buying quite a strong variety of -- of bonds, not only government bonds, also from the private -- from the private sector. We -- we -- we look the risk directly at this. So we are aware that this something that we have to be careful. But we have seen and -- in fact, we have had this discussion quite many times before (inaudible) I have nothing to buy any longer. We managed to do this. And I'm pretty sure at this lower -- at this lower volume that we have decided. We will be able to fulfil our task.

CEHIC: With reinvestment as well, do you see this as in some way upsetting the downsizing of stimulus? Or at least sort of moderating it somewhat?

NOWOTNY: We have declared last week that we have two aspects that are important, the one is the flows, this -- this what they're buying, but increasingly, it is also the stock. So that means we have, of course, quite a strong and increasing stock. And we have decided that we will reinvest these bonds when they become due. So this does have an (inaudible) effect on the markets.

CEHIC: How much could those reinvestments be? Could you put a number on it?

NOWOTNY: We will give numbers, but it's too early to tell now.

CEHIC: In your view, do you have any estimation of -- of -- of what you personally ...

NOWOTNY: It is, it is. It will be quite a substantial number.

CEHIC: Now, I did mention inflation earlier, the fact that it continues to disappoint. And this, of course, is the key thing that the ECB is targeting. This is a problem facing central bankers globally, but specifically in the Eurozone, why do you think we're not seeing inflation picking up?

NOWOTNY: Well, in fact, one has to be quite honest. For next -- for next year, for 2018, our forecasts are that we have even a lower inflation rate than we have 2017. This is mainly due to effects from the energy policy side. Our core inflation, that means inflation without energy, is going up. And here we have kind of a steady development towards high inflation rate in the -- in the range that we want to achieve. So I think we -- we are moving in the right direction. But we have to observe these things going on next year.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, the ECB as a whole doesn't see inflation returning to target before the end of 2019, when do you see it getting to that target, and what's going to drive it?

NOWOTNY: I think that inflation rates in 2018 might be higher than anticipated now because what we see is that energy prices are moving up. So this is one element with regards to core inflation. For core inflation, the most important element are wage developments. Here we have had, not only in Europe but also in the U.S., a rather strange development that it takes a long time for wages to react to the lower unemployment. So this is the famous Phillips curve conundrum that -- that we have. But I think this is just a matter of lags. So after some time, wages will keep up. If we look at the developments just for instance in Germany, where we have just now wage negotiations wages that are quite substantial (inaudible), we will have the same also in my country in Austria.

So I think with -- I'm not sure that these are really, let's say, structural changes, that it might just mean that it takes longer for wages to react to lower unemployment.

CEHIC: OK. So you do see that wage growth coming at some point, but we do hear this from a lot of people that it's coming, that it's coming, but then we're not there yet. So I'm wondering, is the ECB's mandate sits a purpose? Because there's been a lot of discussion about whether that inflation target, not just for the ECB but in general with central banks should actually be modified somewhat.

NOWOTNY: I think central banks should be very, very cautious in modifying their targets. This is also a matter of long-term credibility. On the other hand, we should not reduce this to say it has to be exactly 1.9. So we said from the start on that one has to see this as a medium-term perspective. So I think the most important element is to see what is the direction. And I think the direction is going the right way.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, Mr. Nowotny, visiting our London studios here to meet with Bloomberg News, we're thrilled that he's with us today on "Bloomberg Surveillance." Yves Bonzon with us with Julius Baer. We will continue our discussion, and I really want to talk about the challenges of investment going forward into 2018.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer CIO, is still with us. Yves, we're seeing sterling steady today after the drop yesterday, that dovish hike from the BOE. Just very simply, where do you see the rate hike path going in 2018? The market pushed back its expectations after the decision in the press conference from Mark Carney.

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER: I think there was a clear desire by the central banks to reassure everyone that this is not the beginning of a hard and fast, I think, campaign. The central bank is struggling to explain the wage puzzle, absence of wage growth despite of significant tightening of the labor market. And there's so much uncertainty going on in this country with the Brexit negotiation process being still quite unclear. I think it's prudent for the central banks to actually kind of reload the monetary gun, meaning, by hiking interest rates a little bit, they are making room for accommodation, losing -- if needed, down the road, if eventually worse comes to worst with regards to the Brexit impact.

CEHIC: Yes. And speaking of Brexit, you know, one way that could have interpreted that press conference was that the Bank of England was really tying its forward guidance to Brexit in a way, but of course, that's one of the most uncertain things here. So is there any point in the forward guidance?

BONZON: Well, I guess, they are very pragmatic, you know. I think they are very concerned about communicating well and not surprising investors. And I think it's fair to mention that Brexit is an important unknown, non- unknown but unknown.

CEHIC: Yes. But going back to the wage puzzle then, so one thing that people have said to me is, look, this is about supply side deterioration, and that's where we might eventually get that upward pressure on wages, the Bank of England has used that argument as well itself. Not everyone is convinced by that, though, are you?

BONZON: I'm not actually because I think we have an absence of wage pressure across the skill set spectrum, you know, from low skill and medium skill to even higher skill labor. It's a combination of several things. Technology trends, you know, replacing labor, and sometime labor of the quite skilled kind with automated processes. In -- in the meantime, at the lower end of the skill spectrum, if you think about industry like retailing, these companies are so -- under so much margin pressure, they don't have much room to increase wages actually. So I think the pricing power on the labor side in spite of a relatively tight labor market, is not that great.

Furthermore, I understand social benefit access have been tightened in the U.K., so the -- the relative competition of social benefits, as opposed to low wages, you know, is also (inaudible). So there are so many factor at work, including the gig economy. It's very hard to predict what will happen with wage growth.

KEENE: Yves, I want to go to one of the things of the week that maybe was (inaudible) under the economics, finance, and investment that we do. And that was a remarkable idea of the tech troops showing up at -- in Washington, putting their hands up and testifying and all that. In the summary of -- of this was the power of the European Union to maybe rein in American tech might. I mean, I thought there was a real sea change here. How does it look the prism of Julius Baer as the E.U. tries to regulate the new technology we're all dealing with? Is that a good thing, and will -- will it increase, will Brussels' effort increase in the coming years?

BONZON: There's a very clear and a strong desire by the European Union to intervene in these sectors, on these big tech platforms. They're divided in two group in the world today. You have basically China, which has ringfenced its market and allowed for the development of local giants, and you have the American giants that have invaded the world ex-China. One of the problems, of course, is also in a globalized world the taxation of corporate profits. There seems to be a growing effort in the European Union to find a way to tax these tech platforms. So I think the pressure, the regulatory pressure on them will keep on increasing, but it's a slow process. You see in the European Union, they are struggling to agree because some countries actually benefit from these companies. So it's a -- it's a very long process, I think, but definitely pressure is mounting.

KEENE: But this is really fascinating, folks, and particularly the idea of a European model of entrepreneurship and technology versus an Anglo- American model. Which will win out, Yves, five years out?

BONZON: It's hard to say on the five-year ...

KEENE: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

BONZON: ... on a five-year view who's going to win that, so ...

KEENE: It's Friday.

BONZON: That -- that the -- the U.S. technology platform has such a head start to begin with. When you account for the networking effect, you know, the amount of users that they have managed to gather, give them a head start that which will be hard to overcome. So I think most -- most likely, the -- the main risk for them is regulatory action also on the U.S. side. We have all these discussions with regards to what happened during the election. So again, there -- there -- there is mounting pressure. But on the other end, this is a very strategic industry the United States. And I don't want -- I don't think they want to damage their chances.

CEHIC: Yves, I want to ask you about another piece of regulation, which is PSD2. We talked a lot about MiFID II, but one thing about PSD2 and Europe is that some people are saying, you know, it really could pit European banks against FinTech rivals because of the data issue. And then if we look more globally, you know, there's a lot of talk about whether Amazon could be a challenger for big banks either in the U.S. or globally. How much of a risk are banks in Europe and the U.S. from FinTech rivals because of regulation in Europe? And are they at -- they at more risk than their U.S. rivals?

BONZON: Yes. The extent to which Fintech will compete with traditional finance models is suddenly strongly influenced by regulatory trends and decisions. No question. By the way, one of the problem in Europe is you don't have a (inaudible) regulation across the 27 countries, you know. And that makes the development of start up in Europe far more difficult than it is in the U.S. Now, at the end of the day, finance is about managing a balance sheet, you know, it's balance sheet business. There's a systemic risk involved. So yes, I think there will be venture into the financial industry from FinTech startup. I think still the winners are most likely going to be those of the legacy business model that adapt and leverage on FinTech breakthrough.

CEHIC: Yes. So is it more about then adapting rather than try to find loopholes in the regulation?

BONZON: Absolutely. Yes.

CEHIC: Thank you so much. Yves Bonzon of Julius Baer, where he is a CIO, great to have you with us.

KEENE: Yes, thank you so much, Mr. Bonzon, for joining us on this Friday.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

NOVEMBER 3, 2017

SPEAKERS: EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm delighted to say the ECB governing council member and Austrian National Bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, joins us. And also with us is Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer co-CIO.

Mr. Nowotny, so delighted to have you with us on set. Thank you for joining us. So my first question to you is, should the ECB be downsizing more quickly, given the state of the Eurozone economy, even though inflation is still below target?

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK: Well, we have just made a decision last week.

CEHIC: You have? Was it the right one?

NOWOTNY: Yes, I think it is the right one. And we are having the volume we are buying starting this January of next -- next year for nine months. This reflects that we see that the economy is improving substantially. But we're not yet there where we want to be.

CEHIC: So you're not yet there, but do you think that there should be a more clear end date set for the stimulus or you think it's better to keep that open-ended at this point?

NOWOTNY: Frankly speaking, there had been a discussion about -- about this. There was a clear majority few that one should be flexible, which doesn't mean in my view that we have to go on forever. I think at some time, there will be, of course, reducing and then some kind of -- of an end date. But it's too early now to have this discussion.

CEHIC: But the issue of scarcity is a big one there, do you see any risk of scarcity in the bonds that you're buying?

NOWOTNY: Not really because we are buying quite a strong variety of -- of bonds, not only government bonds, also from the private -- from the private sector. We -- we -- we look the risk directly at this. So we are aware that this something that we have to be careful. But we have seen and -- in fact, we have had this discussion quite many times before (inaudible) I have nothing to buy any longer. We managed to do this. And I'm pretty sure at this lower -- at this lower volume that we have decided. We will be able to fulfil our task.

CEHIC: With reinvestment as well, do you see this as in some way upsetting the downsizing of stimulus? Or at least sort of moderating it somewhat?

NOWOTNY: We have declared last week that we have two aspects that are important, the one is the flows, this -- this what they're buying, but increasingly, it is also the stock. So that means we have, of course, quite a strong and increasing stock. And we have decided that we will reinvest these bonds when they become due. So this does have an (inaudible) effect on the markets.

CEHIC: How much could those reinvestments be? Could you put a number on it?

NOWOTNY: We will give numbers, but it's too early to tell now.

CEHIC: In your view, do you have any estimation of -- of -- of what you personally ...

NOWOTNY: It is, it is. It will be quite a substantial number.

CEHIC: Now, I did mention inflation earlier, the fact that it continues to disappoint. And this, of course, is the key thing that the ECB is targeting. This is a problem facing central bankers globally, but specifically in the Eurozone, why do you think we're not seeing inflation picking up?

NOWOTNY: Well, in fact, one has to be quite honest. For next -- for next year, for 2018, our forecasts are that we have even a lower inflation rate than we have 2017. This is mainly due to effects from the energy policy side. Our core inflation, that means inflation without energy, is going up. And here we have kind of a steady development towards high inflation rate in the -- in the range that we want to achieve. So I think we -- we are moving in the right direction. But we have to observe these things going on next year.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, the ECB as a whole doesn't see inflation returning to target before the end of 2019, when do you see it getting to that target, and what's going to drive it?

NOWOTNY: I think that inflation rates in 2018 might be higher than anticipated now because what we see is that energy prices are moving up. So this is one element with regards to core inflation. For core inflation, the most important element are wage developments. Here we have had, not only in Europe but also in the U.S., a rather strange development that it takes a long time for wages to react to the lower unemployment. So this is the famous Phillips curve conundrum that -- that we have. But I think this is just a matter of lags. So after some time, wages will keep up. If we look at the developments just for instance in Germany, where we have just now wage negotiations wages that are quite substantial (inaudible), we will have the same also in my country in Austria.

So I think with -- I'm not sure that these are really, let's say, structural changes, that it might just mean that it takes longer for wages to react to lower unemployment.

CEHIC: OK. So you do see that wage growth coming at some point, but we do hear this from a lot of people that it's coming, that it's coming, but then we're not there yet. So I'm wondering, is the ECB's mandate sits a purpose? Because there's been a lot of discussion about whether that inflation target, not just for the ECB but in general with central banks should actually be modified somewhat.

NOWOTNY: I think central banks should be very, very cautious in modifying their targets. This is also a matter of long-term credibility. On the other hand, we should not reduce this to say it has to be exactly 1.9. So we said from the start on that one has to see this as a medium-term perspective. So I think the most important element is to see what is the direction. And I think the direction is going the right way.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, Mr. Nowotny, visiting our London studios here to meet with Bloomberg News, we're thrilled that he's with us today on "Bloomberg Surveillance." Yves Bonzon with us with Julius Baer. We will continue our discussion, and I really want to talk about the challenges of investment going forward into 2018.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer CIO, is still with us. Yves, we're seeing sterling steady today after the drop yesterday, that dovish hike from the BOE. Just very simply, where do you see the rate hike path going in 2018? The market pushed back its expectations after the decision in the press conference from Mark Carney.

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER: I think there was a clear desire by the central banks to reassure everyone that this is not the beginning of a hard and fast, I think, campaign. The central bank is struggling to explain the wage puzzle, absence of wage growth despite of significant tightening of the labor market. And there's so much uncertainty going on in this country with the Brexit negotiation process being still quite unclear. I think it's prudent for the central banks to actually kind of reload the monetary gun, meaning, by hiking interest rates a little bit, they are making room for accommodation, losing -- if needed, down the road, if eventually worse comes to worst with regards to the Brexit impact.

CEHIC: Yes. And speaking of Brexit, you know, one way that could have interpreted that press conference was that the Bank of England was really tying its forward guidance to Brexit in a way, but of course, that's one of the most uncertain things here. So is there any point in the forward guidance?

BONZON: Well, I guess, they are very pragmatic, you know. I think they are very concerned about communicating well and not surprising investors. And I think it's fair to mention that Brexit is an important unknown, non- unknown but unknown.

CEHIC: Yes. But going back to the wage puzzle then, so one thing that people have said to me is, look, this is about supply side deterioration, and that's where we might eventually get that upward pressure on wages, the Bank of England has used that argument as well itself. Not everyone is convinced by that, though, are you?

BONZON: I'm not actually because I think we have an absence of wage pressure across the skill set spectrum, you know, from low skill and medium skill to even higher skill labor. It's a combination of several things. Technology trends, you know, replacing labor, and sometime labor of the quite skilled kind with automated processes. In -- in the meantime, at the lower end of the skill spectrum, if you think about industry like retailing, these companies are so -- under so much margin pressure, they don't have much room to increase wages actually. So I think the pricing power on the labor side in spite of a relatively tight labor market, is not that great.

Furthermore, I understand social benefit access have been tightened in the U.K., so the -- the relative competition of social benefits, as opposed to low wages, you know, is also (inaudible). So there are so many factor at work, including the gig economy. It's very hard to predict what will happen with wage growth.

KEENE: Yves, I want to go to one of the things of the week that maybe was (inaudible) under the economics, finance, and investment that we do. And that was a remarkable idea of the tech troops showing up at -- in Washington, putting their hands up and testifying and all that. In the summary of -- of this was the power of the European Union to maybe rein in American tech might. I mean, I thought there was a real sea change here. How does it look the prism of Julius Baer as the E.U. tries to regulate the new technology we're all dealing with? Is that a good thing, and will -- will it increase, will Brussels' effort increase in the coming years?

BONZON: There's a very clear and a strong desire by the European Union to intervene in these sectors, on these big tech platforms. They're divided in two group in the world today. You have basically China, which has ringfenced its market and allowed for the development of local giants, and you have the American giants that have invaded the world ex-China. One of the problems, of course, is also in a globalized world the taxation of corporate profits. There seems to be a growing effort in the European Union to find a way to tax these tech platforms. So I think the pressure, the regulatory pressure on them will keep on increasing, but it's a slow process. You see in the European Union, they are struggling to agree because some countries actually benefit from these companies. So it's a -- it's a very long process, I think, but definitely pressure is mounting.

KEENE: But this is really fascinating, folks, and particularly the idea of a European model of entrepreneurship and technology versus an Anglo- American model. Which will win out, Yves, five years out?

BONZON: It's hard to say on the five-year ...

KEENE: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

BONZON: ... on a five-year view who's going to win that, so ...

KEENE: It's Friday.

BONZON: That -- that the -- the U.S. technology platform has such a head start to begin with. When you account for the networking effect, you know, the amount of users that they have managed to gather, give them a head start that which will be hard to overcome. So I think most -- most likely, the -- the main risk for them is regulatory action also on the U.S. side. We have all these discussions with regards to what happened during the election. So again, there -- there -- there is mounting pressure. But on the other end, this is a very strategic industry the United States. And I don't want -- I don't think they want to damage their chances.

CEHIC: Yves, I want to ask you about another piece of regulation, which is PSD2. We talked a lot about MiFID II, but one thing about PSD2 and Europe is that some people are saying, you know, it really could pit European banks against FinTech rivals because of the data issue. And then if we look more globally, you know, there's a lot of talk about whether Amazon could be a challenger for big banks either in the U.S. or globally. How much of a risk are banks in Europe and the U.S. from FinTech rivals because of regulation in Europe? And are they at -- they at more risk than their U.S. rivals?

BONZON: Yes. The extent to which Fintech will compete with traditional finance models is suddenly strongly influenced by regulatory trends and decisions. No question. By the way, one of the problem in Europe is you don't have a (inaudible) regulation across the 27 countries, you know. And that makes the development of start up in Europe far more difficult than it is in the U.S. Now, at the end of the day, finance is about managing a balance sheet, you know, it's balance sheet business. There's a systemic risk involved. So yes, I think there will be venture into the financial industry from FinTech startup. I think still the winners are most likely going to be those of the legacy business model that adapt and leverage on FinTech breakthrough.

CEHIC: Yes. So is it more about then adapting rather than try to find loopholes in the regulation?

BONZON: Absolutely. Yes.

CEHIC: Thank you so much. Yves Bonzon of Julius Baer, where he is a CIO, great to have you with us.

KEENE: Yes, thank you so much, Mr. Bonzon, for joining us on this Friday.

Ewald Nowotny and Julius Baer discuss global ecomonics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

NOVEMBER 3, 2017

SPEAKERS: EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm delighted to say the ECB governing council member and Austrian National Bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, joins us. And also with us is Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer co-CIO.

Mr. Nowotny, so delighted to have you with us on set. Thank you for joining us. So my first question to you is, should the ECB be downsizing more quickly, given the state of the Eurozone economy, even though inflation is still below target?

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK: Well, we have just made a decision last week.

CEHIC: You have? Was it the right one?

NOWOTNY: Yes, I think it is the right one. And we are having the volume we are buying starting this January of next -- next year for nine months. This reflects that we see that the economy is improving substantially. But we're not yet there where we want to be.

CEHIC: So you're not yet there, but do you think that there should be a more clear end date set for the stimulus or you think it's better to keep that open-ended at this point?

NOWOTNY: Frankly speaking, there had been a discussion about -- about this. There was a clear majority few that one should be flexible, which doesn't mean in my view that we have to go on forever. I think at some time, there will be, of course, reducing and then some kind of -- of an end date. But it's too early now to have this discussion.

CEHIC: But the issue of scarcity is a big one there, do you see any risk of scarcity in the bonds that you're buying?

NOWOTNY: Not really because we are buying quite a strong variety of -- of bonds, not only government bonds, also from the private -- from the private sector. We -- we -- we look the risk directly at this. So we are aware that this something that we have to be careful. But we have seen and -- in fact, we have had this discussion quite many times before (inaudible) I have nothing to buy any longer. We managed to do this. And I'm pretty sure at this lower -- at this lower volume that we have decided. We will be able to fulfil our task.

CEHIC: With reinvestment as well, do you see this as in some way upsetting the downsizing of stimulus? Or at least sort of moderating it somewhat?

NOWOTNY: We have declared last week that we have two aspects that are important, the one is the flows, this -- this what they're buying, but increasingly, it is also the stock. So that means we have, of course, quite a strong and increasing stock. And we have decided that we will reinvest these bonds when they become due. So this does have an (inaudible) effect on the markets.

CEHIC: How much could those reinvestments be? Could you put a number on it?

NOWOTNY: We will give numbers, but it's too early to tell now.

CEHIC: In your view, do you have any estimation of -- of -- of what you personally ...

NOWOTNY: It is, it is. It will be quite a substantial number.

CEHIC: Now, I did mention inflation earlier, the fact that it continues to disappoint. And this, of course, is the key thing that the ECB is targeting. This is a problem facing central bankers globally, but specifically in the Eurozone, why do you think we're not seeing inflation picking up?

NOWOTNY: Well, in fact, one has to be quite honest. For next -- for next year, for 2018, our forecasts are that we have even a lower inflation rate than we have 2017. This is mainly due to effects from the energy policy side. Our core inflation, that means inflation without energy, is going up. And here we have kind of a steady development towards high inflation rate in the -- in the range that we want to achieve. So I think we -- we are moving in the right direction. But we have to observe these things going on next year.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, the ECB as a whole doesn't see inflation returning to target before the end of 2019, when do you see it getting to that target, and what's going to drive it?

NOWOTNY: I think that inflation rates in 2018 might be higher than anticipated now because what we see is that energy prices are moving up. So this is one element with regards to core inflation. For core inflation, the most important element are wage developments. Here we have had, not only in Europe but also in the U.S., a rather strange development that it takes a long time for wages to react to the lower unemployment. So this is the famous Phillips curve conundrum that -- that we have. But I think this is just a matter of lags. So after some time, wages will keep up. If we look at the developments just for instance in Germany, where we have just now wage negotiations wages that are quite substantial (inaudible), we will have the same also in my country in Austria.

So I think with -- I'm not sure that these are really, let's say, structural changes, that it might just mean that it takes longer for wages to react to lower unemployment.

CEHIC: OK. So you do see that wage growth coming at some point, but we do hear this from a lot of people that it's coming, that it's coming, but then we're not there yet. So I'm wondering, is the ECB's mandate sits a purpose? Because there's been a lot of discussion about whether that inflation target, not just for the ECB but in general with central banks should actually be modified somewhat.

NOWOTNY: I think central banks should be very, very cautious in modifying their targets. This is also a matter of long-term credibility. On the other hand, we should not reduce this to say it has to be exactly 1.9. So we said from the start on that one has to see this as a medium-term perspective. So I think the most important element is to see what is the direction. And I think the direction is going the right way.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, Mr. Nowotny, visiting our London studios here to meet with Bloomberg News, we're thrilled that he's with us today on "Bloomberg Surveillance." Yves Bonzon with us with Julius Baer. We will continue our discussion, and I really want to talk about the challenges of investment going forward into 2018.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer CIO, is still with us. Yves, we're seeing sterling steady today after the drop yesterday, that dovish hike from the BOE. Just very simply, where do you see the rate hike path going in 2018? The market pushed back its expectations after the decision in the press conference from Mark Carney.

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER: I think there was a clear desire by the central banks to reassure everyone that this is not the beginning of a hard and fast, I think, campaign. The central bank is struggling to explain the wage puzzle, absence of wage growth despite of significant tightening of the labor market. And there's so much uncertainty going on in this country with the Brexit negotiation process being still quite unclear. I think it's prudent for the central banks to actually kind of reload the monetary gun, meaning, by hiking interest rates a little bit, they are making room for accommodation, losing -- if needed, down the road, if eventually worse comes to worst with regards to the Brexit impact.

CEHIC: Yes. And speaking of Brexit, you know, one way that could have interpreted that press conference was that the Bank of England was really tying its forward guidance to Brexit in a way, but of course, that's one of the most uncertain things here. So is there any point in the forward guidance?

BONZON: Well, I guess, they are very pragmatic, you know. I think they are very concerned about communicating well and not surprising investors. And I think it's fair to mention that Brexit is an important unknown, non- unknown but unknown.

CEHIC: Yes. But going back to the wage puzzle then, so one thing that people have said to me is, look, this is about supply side deterioration, and that's where we might eventually get that upward pressure on wages, the Bank of England has used that argument as well itself. Not everyone is convinced by that, though, are you?

BONZON: I'm not actually because I think we have an absence of wage pressure across the skill set spectrum, you know, from low skill and medium skill to even higher skill labor. It's a combination of several things. Technology trends, you know, replacing labor, and sometime labor of the quite skilled kind with automated processes. In -- in the meantime, at the lower end of the skill spectrum, if you think about industry like retailing, these companies are so -- under so much margin pressure, they don't have much room to increase wages actually. So I think the pricing power on the labor side in spite of a relatively tight labor market, is not that great.

Furthermore, I understand social benefit access have been tightened in the U.K., so the -- the relative competition of social benefits, as opposed to low wages, you know, is also (inaudible). So there are so many factor at work, including the gig economy. It's very hard to predict what will happen with wage growth.

KEENE: Yves, I want to go to one of the things of the week that maybe was (inaudible) under the economics, finance, and investment that we do. And that was a remarkable idea of the tech troops showing up at -- in Washington, putting their hands up and testifying and all that. In the summary of -- of this was the power of the European Union to maybe rein in American tech might. I mean, I thought there was a real sea change here. How does it look the prism of Julius Baer as the E.U. tries to regulate the new technology we're all dealing with? Is that a good thing, and will -- will it increase, will Brussels' effort increase in the coming years?

BONZON: There's a very clear and a strong desire by the European Union to intervene in these sectors, on these big tech platforms. They're divided in two group in the world today. You have basically China, which has ringfenced its market and allowed for the development of local giants, and you have the American giants that have invaded the world ex-China. One of the problems, of course, is also in a globalized world the taxation of corporate profits. There seems to be a growing effort in the European Union to find a way to tax these tech platforms. So I think the pressure, the regulatory pressure on them will keep on increasing, but it's a slow process. You see in the European Union, they are struggling to agree because some countries actually benefit from these companies. So it's a -- it's a very long process, I think, but definitely pressure is mounting.

KEENE: But this is really fascinating, folks, and particularly the idea of a European model of entrepreneurship and technology versus an Anglo- American model. Which will win out, Yves, five years out?

BONZON: It's hard to say on the five-year ...

KEENE: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

BONZON: ... on a five-year view who's going to win that, so ...

KEENE: It's Friday.

BONZON: That -- that the -- the U.S. technology platform has such a head start to begin with. When you account for the networking effect, you know, the amount of users that they have managed to gather, give them a head start that which will be hard to overcome. So I think most -- most likely, the -- the main risk for them is regulatory action also on the U.S. side. We have all these discussions with regards to what happened during the election. So again, there -- there -- there is mounting pressure. But on the other end, this is a very strategic industry the United States. And I don't want -- I don't think they want to damage their chances.

CEHIC: Yves, I want to ask you about another piece of regulation, which is PSD2. We talked a lot about MiFID II, but one thing about PSD2 and Europe is that some people are saying, you know, it really could pit European banks against FinTech rivals because of the data issue. And then if we look more globally, you know, there's a lot of talk about whether Amazon could be a challenger for big banks either in the U.S. or globally. How much of a risk are banks in Europe and the U.S. from FinTech rivals because of regulation in Europe? And are they at -- they at more risk than their U.S. rivals?

BONZON: Yes. The extent to which Fintech will compete with traditional finance models is suddenly strongly influenced by regulatory trends and decisions. No question. By the way, one of the problem in Europe is you don't have a (inaudible) regulation across the 27 countries, you know. And that makes the development of start up in Europe far more difficult than it is in the U.S. Now, at the end of the day, finance is about managing a balance sheet, you know, it's balance sheet business. There's a systemic risk involved. So yes, I think there will be venture into the financial industry from FinTech startup. I think still the winners are most likely going to be those of the legacy business model that adapt and leverage on FinTech breakthrough.

CEHIC: Yes. So is it more about then adapting rather than try to find loopholes in the regulation?

BONZON: Absolutely. Yes.

CEHIC: Thank you so much. Yves Bonzon of Julius Baer, where he is a CIO, great to have you with us.

KEENE: Yes, thank you so much, Mr. Bonzon, for joining us on this Friday.

Ewald Nowotny and Julius Baer discuss global ecomonics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK; AND YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

NOVEMBER 3, 2017

SPEAKERS: EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] NEJRA CEHIC, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm delighted to say the ECB governing council member and Austrian National Bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, joins us. And also with us is Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer co-CIO.

Mr. Nowotny, so delighted to have you with us on set. Thank you for joining us. So my first question to you is, should the ECB be downsizing more quickly, given the state of the Eurozone economy, even though inflation is still below target?

EWALD NOWOTNY, GOVERNING COUNCIL MEMBER, EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK: Well, we have just made a decision last week.

CEHIC: You have? Was it the right one?

NOWOTNY: Yes, I think it is the right one. And we are having the volume we are buying starting this January of next -- next year for nine months. This reflects that we see that the economy is improving substantially. But we're not yet there where we want to be.

CEHIC: So you're not yet there, but do you think that there should be a more clear end date set for the stimulus or you think it's better to keep that open-ended at this point?

NOWOTNY: Frankly speaking, there had been a discussion about -- about this. There was a clear majority few that one should be flexible, which doesn't mean in my view that we have to go on forever. I think at some time, there will be, of course, reducing and then some kind of -- of an end date. But it's too early now to have this discussion.

CEHIC: But the issue of scarcity is a big one there, do you see any risk of scarcity in the bonds that you're buying?

NOWOTNY: Not really because we are buying quite a strong variety of -- of bonds, not only government bonds, also from the private -- from the private sector. We -- we -- we look the risk directly at this. So we are aware that this something that we have to be careful. But we have seen and -- in fact, we have had this discussion quite many times before (inaudible) I have nothing to buy any longer. We managed to do this. And I'm pretty sure at this lower -- at this lower volume that we have decided. We will be able to fulfil our task.

CEHIC: With reinvestment as well, do you see this as in some way upsetting the downsizing of stimulus? Or at least sort of moderating it somewhat?

NOWOTNY: We have declared last week that we have two aspects that are important, the one is the flows, this -- this what they're buying, but increasingly, it is also the stock. So that means we have, of course, quite a strong and increasing stock. And we have decided that we will reinvest these bonds when they become due. So this does have an (inaudible) effect on the markets.

CEHIC: How much could those reinvestments be? Could you put a number on it?

NOWOTNY: We will give numbers, but it's too early to tell now.

CEHIC: In your view, do you have any estimation of -- of -- of what you personally ...

NOWOTNY: It is, it is. It will be quite a substantial number.

CEHIC: Now, I did mention inflation earlier, the fact that it continues to disappoint. And this, of course, is the key thing that the ECB is targeting. This is a problem facing central bankers globally, but specifically in the Eurozone, why do you think we're not seeing inflation picking up?

NOWOTNY: Well, in fact, one has to be quite honest. For next -- for next year, for 2018, our forecasts are that we have even a lower inflation rate than we have 2017. This is mainly due to effects from the energy policy side. Our core inflation, that means inflation without energy, is going up. And here we have kind of a steady development towards high inflation rate in the -- in the range that we want to achieve. So I think we -- we are moving in the right direction. But we have to observe these things going on next year.

CEHIC: Yes. I mean, the ECB as a whole doesn't see inflation returning to target before the end of 2019, when do you see it getting to that target, and what's going to drive it?

NOWOTNY: I think that inflation rates in 2018 might be higher than anticipated now because what we see is that energy prices are moving up. So this is one element with regards to core inflation. For core inflation, the most important element are wage developments. Here we have had, not only in Europe but also in the U.S., a rather strange development that it takes a long time for wages to react to the lower unemployment. So this is the famous Phillips curve conundrum that -- that we have. But I think this is just a matter of lags. So after some time, wages will keep up. If we look at the developments just for instance in Germany, where we have just now wage negotiations wages that are quite substantial (inaudible), we will have the same also in my country in Austria.

So I think with -- I'm not sure that these are really, let's say, structural changes, that it might just mean that it takes longer for wages to react to lower unemployment.

CEHIC: OK. So you do see that wage growth coming at some point, but we do hear this from a lot of people that it's coming, that it's coming, but then we're not there yet. So I'm wondering, is the ECB's mandate sits a purpose? Because there's been a lot of discussion about whether that inflation target, not just for the ECB but in general with central banks should actually be modified somewhat.

NOWOTNY: I think central banks should be very, very cautious in modifying their targets. This is also a matter of long-term credibility. On the other hand, we should not reduce this to say it has to be exactly 1.9. So we said from the start on that one has to see this as a medium-term perspective. So I think the most important element is to see what is the direction. And I think the direction is going the right way.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, Mr. Nowotny, visiting our London studios here to meet with Bloomberg News, we're thrilled that he's with us today on "Bloomberg Surveillance." Yves Bonzon with us with Julius Baer. We will continue our discussion, and I really want to talk about the challenges of investment going forward into 2018.

(BREAK)

CEHIC: Yves Bonzon, Bank Julius Baer CIO, is still with us. Yves, we're seeing sterling steady today after the drop yesterday, that dovish hike from the BOE. Just very simply, where do you see the rate hike path going in 2018? The market pushed back its expectations after the decision in the press conference from Mark Carney.

YVES BONZON, CIO, JULIUS BAER: I think there was a clear desire by the central banks to reassure everyone that this is not the beginning of a hard and fast, I think, campaign. The central bank is struggling to explain the wage puzzle, absence of wage growth despite of significant tightening of the labor market. And there's so much uncertainty going on in this country with the Brexit negotiation process being still quite unclear. I think it's prudent for the central banks to actually kind of reload the monetary gun, meaning, by hiking interest rates a little bit, they are making room for accommodation, losing -- if needed, down the road, if eventually worse comes to worst with regards to the Brexit impact.

CEHIC: Yes. And speaking of Brexit, you know, one way that could have interpreted that press conference was that the Bank of England was really tying its forward guidance to Brexit in a way, but of course, that's one of the most uncertain things here. So is there any point in the forward guidance?

BONZON: Well, I guess, they are very pragmatic, you know. I think they are very concerned about communicating well and not surprising investors. And I think it's fair to mention that Brexit is an important unknown, non- unknown but unknown.

CEHIC: Yes. But going back to the wage puzzle then, so one thing that people have said to me is, look, this is about supply side deterioration, and that's where we might eventually get that upward pressure on wages, the Bank of England has used that argument as well itself. Not everyone is convinced by that, though, are you?

So I think the pricing power on the labor side in spite of a relatively tight labor market, is not that great.
