KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, FOX NEWS HOST: So she still wants to include him on her special and luckily, an adorable substitute was ready to step in -- his two-year-old baby brother Clay donned a Marine uniform identical to her brother's.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: Very cute.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: That was wonderful.

GUILFOYLE: All right. SPECIAL REPORT is up next. Hey -- Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS CHIEF POLITICAL ANCHOR: Hey -- Kimberly. Thank you.

President Trump kicks out dozens of Russians. As this continues -- the Russian situation over the British spy poisoning incident, the Kremlin vows to retaliate.

The fallout over the Stormy Daniels interview as the porn stars attorney says there is more evidence to come.

And the stock market soars with the Dow having the biggest point gain since 2008.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. I'm Bret Baier.

The U.S. and more than a dozen European nations are expelling more than 100 Russian diplomats/intelligence officers/spies tonight in a unified show of condemnation over the poisoning of a former Russian spy earlier this month in England. The Kremlin which has steadfastly denied involvement says it will proceed from a principle of reciprocity.

Correspondent Kevin Corke starts us off tonight from the White House. Good evening -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening there -- Bret.

This wave of expulsions comes after officials both in the U.S. and in Europe pointed to strong evidence that suggested, they say, that the Russians were behind that deadly, certainly dangerous, nerve agent attack on a former Russian spy on British soil. And that, they say, was the solid basis for further action.

In expelling 60 Russian diplomats the U.S. joined governments across the globe in punishing the Kremlin for a nerve agent attack on a former Russian spy on British soil, an action the White House today called brazen and reckless.

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE PRINCIPAL DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: We think that this is not just an important message to send to the Russian government but it's also, you know, significant in degrading their intelligence capabilities around the world, not just in the United States.

Along with the U.S., more than a dozen European Union countries, Ukraine, and Canada all took action affecting more than 100 individuals in the biggest western expulsion of Russian diplomats since the height of the Cold War.

British Prime Minister Theresa May called the international response the clearest indication yet of world solidarity against Moscow.

THERESA MAY, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: It is part of a pattern of increasingly aggressive Russian behavior. But also represents the new and dangerous phase in Russia's hostile activity against Europe and our shared values and interests.

CORKE: Kremlin officials have denied being behind the attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia. But they remain in critical condition.

Also today, the White House announced the closure of a Russian facility in Seattle, just the latest in a series of actions directed toward the Kremlin by the Trump administration countering a frequent narrative from critics who often accuse Mr. Trump of being soft on Moscow.

The President previously ordered a cruise missile attack against Syria's Bashar al-Assad. He expanded sanctions on Moscow, gave lethal aid to neighboring Ukraine, sent troops into Poland over Russian objections and expanded oil exports into eastern Europe -- a crucial Russian economic market.

ANATOLY ANTONOV, RUSSIAN AMBASSADOR TO THE U.S. (through translator): What the United States of America do today is they are destroying the little that is left from the Russian-American relations. The United States is wholly responsible for the destruction of Russian-American relations.

JON HUNTSMAN, U.S. AMBASSADOR TO RUSSIA: The bonds between our people remain strong. The United States is ready to cooperate and forge a better relationship between our two countries. But that will only be possible when Russia chooses to become a more responsible partner.

CORKE: Joel Rosenberg, author of the bestselling book "the Kremlin Conspiracy" warns the latest moves by the White House are only a solid first step.

JOEL ROSENBERG, AUTHOR: President Trump has to do much more. He needs to toughen up economic sanctions and really hit Putin's money, the oligarchs' money. And he needs to start putting more deterrent forces in Europe close to Russia's border.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Very interesting conversation there. By the way, Bret, we also heard from the Russian Kremlin spokesman, Dmitry Paskov. He says that his country would be guided by the principle of reciprocity in reaction to what happened today, which is a not-so-subtle way of saying that dozens of American diplomats could soon be making their way home -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin Corke, live on the north lawn. Kevin -- thank you.

Let's talk about the effects of the diplomatic expulsions. Senior political analyst Brit Hume is here with us tonight.

Good evening -- Brit. Your thoughts on this and what it means.

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Well, this is another example of, I think a key lesson that people need to learn about the Trump administration which is that what the President says and what he does are frequently very different indeed.

All those things that Kevin just ticked off that the President has done undermine Russian interests in many ways. Indeed our whole energy policy undermines Russian interest because it holds oil prices down and the Russian economy really is built on that. It has been described, as you know Bret, as a gas station with nuclear weapons.

So that's but one example.

These expulsions today are another. You know, that follows the closing of the consulate in San Francisco earlier still. And meanwhile, of course, the President is calling Putin on the phone to congratulate him on his victory. And in many ways he's acting as if he's got a deep hunch that he and Vladimir Putin are going to compose their relationship and have a real cooperative arrangement.

But the actions he has taken do not indicate that he is pursuing that, at least in terms of what he is doing. So this is one example.

There are many others. But that is something that we need to keep an eye on. Watch what he does, not so much what he says.

BAIER: Yes. As you said, the critics are very loud and boisterous that the President is not saying the right things and that he is not communicating the message publicly. But yet the list of things we just saw in Kevin's piece obviously is action.

HUME: Yes. And look at another area here. The President comes out and says, you know, trade wars are easy to win. And he imposes these sanctions on steel and aluminum. And the next thing you know, of course, he's exempting allies right and left from that. And now despite the fact that there is supposed to be in effect with China we learned today, and the stock market certainly noticed today, that negotiations are now underway to work something out with China.

Again a case of saying one thing and the actions tend to point in another direction, proving that as in so many instances, the President's bark is worse than his bite.

BAIER: Where do you think this goes with Russia? Do you think, Brit, this is the beginning of another Cold War in essence?

HUME: Well, I think that, you know, relations are pretty tense. And I think it's almost certainly true that there will be expulsions of Americans or other measures taken by Russia to respond to this.

But the question then becomes, all right, once that's done, what is the message that Vladimir Putin takes away from these actions? I think he will probably take away the notion that President Trump, while he would like to have a good relationship with him, is not really going to be pushed around and that could lead in a positive direction.

Putin is a hard-eyed man who I think understands actions do obviously speak louder than words. And there may be a chance after this settles down a little bit to forge a more cooperative relationship that would have to be based on Russian behavior.

And as the analyst that you quoted in the earlier piece noted, there are still further actions the U.S. could take that are well short of any military action or I think, you know, truly, deeply belligerent that would make a difference in Russia. So we will see but we've got a long way to go here.

BAIER: Brit -- as always, thank you.

HUME: You bet -- Bret.

BAIER: Do you agree with the expulsion of the Russian diplomats? Let us know. Do you think the Trump administration has been strong enough when it comes to Russia? Let me know on Twitter @BretBaier, you can use the #SpecialReport; or on Facebook at facebook.com/BretBaierSR.

Back here at home, stocks surged today on Wall Street. The Dow jumped 669 -- that is its biggest one-day point gain in ten years. The S&P 500 was up 70. The Nasdaq finished ahead 228. It is the best day in 17 years.

Let's talk about that. Where the market is today, why, and maybe where it's going.

Deirdre Bolton of the Fox Business Network joins us from New York. Good evening -- Deirdre, big day.

DEIDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good evening -- Bret, it certainly is.

So today's high highs make up about half of last week's low lows. You said it -- the Dow posting its biggest one-day point gain in about a decade, so more than 650 points up, and all three indices logging their biggest rally since August 2015.

So investors saw evidence of trade solutions instead of a trade war and that helped sentiment.

ON Sunday U.S. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin has said the administration was quote, "working on a pathway to see if we, the U.S. can reach an agreement as to what fair trade is for them, meaning China. So it seems as if U.S. officials are meeting with Chinese officials behind closed doors, away from the press, quietly seeking trade agreements and a completely different tone to what we had last week which was angry public rhetoric on both sides.

So tech stocks closed higher today as well. That also helped overall sentiment. Even Facebook closed slightly higher after losing about 10 percent in the past five trading days.

So Facebook has a tough road ahead though. For the second time since 2011, the FTC is investigating the company's privacy practices. The Senate Judiciary Committee also inviting, but that means they probably can't say no, the CEOs of Facebook, Twitter, and Google to testify in D.C. on April 10. So more to come on privacy, big tech, and potential regulations.

In the meantime, Bret -- back to you.

BAIER: All right. Deirdre - -thank you.

The chief law enforcement officers for 37 states and territories are demanding to know when Facebook learned of a huge breach of privacy protections. Meanwhile the social media site is going old school, using newspapers, of all things, to try to express its sorrow and commitment to change.

National correspondent William La Jeunesse reports tonight from Los Angeles.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: We have a basic responsibility to protect people's data.

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: That statement by CEO Mark Zuckerberg carries new meaning today with the announcement on the Federal Trade Commission's investigation into the social media giant.

SAM LESTER, ELECTRONIC PRIVACY INFORMATION CENTER: Facebook represented to its users that it had certain privacy protections in place when in fact, it didn't.

LA JEUNESSE: In 2011, Facebook agreed with an FTC mandate to obtain user permission before sharing personal data with third-party apps. Critics say the company repeatedly violated that and the watchdog until now has shown no teeth.

LESTER: If Facebook had complied with this consent order and if the FTC had done its job and enforced it, then this whole mess with Cambridge Analytica never would have happened.

LA JEUNESSE: This weekend, Zuckerberg apologized in a full-page ad though polls show many users already lost trust.

SATITA (PH), UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA: This isn't really a personal issue of personal apology. It's really about public policy, consumer harm, consumer protection.

LA JEUNESSE: Last week the House Energy and Commerce Committee asked Zuckerberg to testify on Capitol Hill. Today Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley did as well in a data privacy hearing scheduled for April 10.

SENATOR MARK WARNER (D), VIRGINIA: I think Mr. Zuckerberg needs to come and testify before Congress, not just put an advertisement in the newspaper.

LA JEUNESSE: Any inquiry will also involve Cambridge Analytica which according to the "Washington Post" allowed dozens of foreign nationals to work in 2014 U.S. election campaigns in violation of U.S. law.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: And the latest controversy for Facebook, an allegation that it kept logs of phone calls and texts of Android users using the Facebook messenger without their explicit consent. The company claims by simply signing up, users opted in -- Bret.

BAIER: William -- thank you.

The President does not believe anyone threatened adult movie actress Stormy Daniels who alleges a sexual encounter with Mr. Trump. That came from the President's spokesman this afternoon after last nights interview with Daniels on "60 Minutes". The President's lawyers demanding an apology for the implication he might have been involved.

Tonight Fox News media analyst and host of Fox's "MEDIA BUZZ" Howard Kurtz has a recap of the Stormy Daniels interview.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STORMY DANIELS, DONALD TRUMP ACCUSER: This is not a "me too". I was not a victim. I've never said I was a victim

HOWARD KURTZ, FOX NEWS MEDIA ANALYST: Stormy Daniels, as expected, told CBS' Anderson Cooper that she had a one-time sexual encounter with Donald Trump a dozen years ago.

But some journalists are saying today that the porn actress failed to prove her other allegations and her lawyer, Michael Avenatti, drew criticism on the morning shows including "The View" for overhyping the "60 Minutes" appearance.

Avenatti had tweeted a picture of a CD, implying his client might have photos or texts involving Trump but she refused to discuss that on CBS.

Daniels said that back in 2011 when she was going to tell her tale to a magazine, a man confronted her in a parking lot and told her to leave Trump alone and forget the story.

DANIELS: And then he leaned around and looked at my daughter and said that's a beautiful little girl. It would be a shame if something happened to her mom.

KURTZ: But Daniels says she can't identify the man and didn't go the police making the account impossible for others to verify.

Daniels said she accepted a $130,000 nondisclosure deal from Trump attorney Michael Cohen because she didn't want the story to come out. And she said she later felt pressured, as recently as January, into releasing statements denying any affair.

DANIELS: As a matter of fact, the exact sentence used was "They can make your life hell in many different ways."

ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST: "They" being --

DANIELS: I'm not exactly sure who "they" were. I believed it to be Michael Cohen.

KURTZ: That speculation led Cohen to strongly deny any involvement in any pressure and his lawyer to send her a cease-and-desist letter.

And today -- a White House denial.

SHAH: He's denied the accusations that she made last night and has been consistent in doing so. She is not.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KURTZ: And late today in California, Stormy Daniels' attorney expanded her legal complaint to include (ph) presidential attorney Michael Cohen of defamation.

"60 Minutes" scored its biggest ratings in a decade. And the Daniels suit and litigation by other accusers might lead to legal complications for the President. But in the court of public opinion, the Stormy sit-down didn't seem to move the needle -- Bret.

BAIER: Howie -- thank you.

Up next, is the U.S. being drawn in further to the Yemen civil war? We will take a look there.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 40 in Sacramento where the family of an unarmed African-American man shot 20 times by police is calling for an independent investigation of his death. Twenty-two-year-old Stephon Clark was killed in the backyard of his grandparents' home last week. Police say they thought the cell phone he was holding was a gun. Clark's grandmother asked why officers did not use a taser or other nonlethal force.

WDRB in Louisville as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says he will try to bring hemp production back into the mainstream. The Kentucky senator says he will introduce legislation to legalize hemp as an agricultural commodity. Kentucky is one of several states using hemp for research.

And this is a live look at Orlando from Fox 35, our affiliate there. The big story there tonight, lawyers for the wife of the Pulse Nightclub shooter asked for a mistrial after learning her father's -- her husband's father rather, was an informant for the FBI for 11 years. The judge denied the ruling late this afternoon. Noor Salman is accused of aiding her husband in the attack that killed 49 people in June of 2016. Her attorneys say the information about her father-in-law should have been disclosed earlier.

That is tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We'll be right back.

BAIER: This is a Fox News alert.

A senior U.S. Defense official confirms to Fox News federal agents have found several suspicious packages delivered to military locations in the Washington area. The official says the destinations include Fort Belvoir, Fort McNair, and the Dahlgren Naval Service Warfare Center. One of those packages reportedly tested positive for black powder and residue. The packages are being examined at the FBI laboratory in Quantico, Virginia.

We will bring you any late breaking details.

There are reports tonight a high level North Korean official is in Beijing. Bloomberg, citing three sources, has even said it is North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. There has been no confirmation of this at this hour, including from the White House. Kim Jong-un has not made an international trip since taking power in 2011 in North Korea.

There is considerable confusion tonight about just how effective Saudi Arabia's U.S.-supplied missile defense system has been against rocket attacks from Shiite rebels in Yemen.

Correspondent Conor Powell is watching that story from our Middle East newsroom.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CONOR POWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yemen's Houthi rebels celebrating as they fired a barrage of missiles into Saudi Arabia. At least three made it as far as Riyadh, the Kingdom's capital. One person was killed and two injured.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: At 11:00 p.m., we woke up to a loud sound. We rushed and ran out of the room as the explosion took place over the house.

POWELL: Saudi state TV claimed all the missiles were intercepted but this video shows a U.S.-made Patriot antimissile changing course in midair and crashing.

Last night's attack comes on the third anniversary of the Saudi-led coalition launching military operations against the Houthis in what many see as a proxy fight between Tehran and Riyadh. The State Department condemned the attack, saying "We support the right of our Saudi partners to defend their borders against these threats."

The conflict in Yemen though is turning into a humanitarian disaster with more than 10,000 people dead and eight million now on the verge of starvation.

Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is in the U.S. trying to shore up support for the war. America is a major arms supplier to Saudi Arabia. And the Pentagon has advisors in Riyadh. But there are growing concerns on Capitol Hill about America's participation in the conflict.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

POWELL: A bipartisan congressional effort to remove U.S. forces from the conflict in Yemen was recently defeated, and President Trump has developed a close working relationship with the Saudi Crown Prince with an eye towards ramping up the pressure on Iran -- Bret.

BAIER: Conor Powell in our Middle East newsroom. Conor -- thank you.

Two al Qaeda militants have been killed in the first U.S. drone strike in Libya against the terror group. The U.S. African command says no civilians were hurt in the city of Ubari located in the Sahara desert. The Pentagon says al Qaeda has used southern Libya as a staging point for operations for some time.

Back here in the U.S., gun maker Remington is filing for bankruptcy protection. The company makes the Bushmaster AR-15 style rifle that was used in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shootings. AR-15 style rifles have been used in other mass shootings like the recent school shooting in Parkland, Florida as well as the Las Vegas massacre. Remington has faced falling sales and lawsuits tied to that massacre since 2012.

Over the weekend, survivors of the school shootings in Parkland, Florida, led a nationwide effort to promote gun control. The epicenter of the movement was Washington, D.C., but the effects could be felt all over.

Correspondent Garrett Tenney looks at what happened.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GARRET TENNEY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets this past weekend to protest gun violence. Organizers of the student-led March for Our lives rallies are calling it the start of a movement and a wake-up call for Congress ahead of this year's midterm elections.

DELANEY TARR, DOUGLAS HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The pressure is on for every person in power, and it will stay that way because they know what is coming. They know that if there is no assault weapons ban passed then we will vote them out.

TENNEY: The latest Fox News poll found overwhelming support for specific gun-control measures, including 91 percent of voters who are in favor of universal background checks on all gun buyers; 72 percent support raising the minimum age to buy a gun to 21; and 60 percent in favor of banning assault rifles and semi-automatic weapons.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And the motion is adopted --

TENNEY: Congress did include several reforms in its $1.3 trillion spending bill last week. Strengthening background checks and providing funding for school safety measures. But activists argue those measures aren't enough and Democrats are hoping that frustration will help them in November.

SENATOR TIM KAINE (D), VIRGINIA: The activism in these young people is actually changing the equation.

TENNEY: Gun control will be a complicated issue for Democrats particularly in the Senate where they're defending seats in states like West Virginia, North Dakota, Missouri, and Indiana where there is strong support for the Second Amendment.

GUY BENSON, TOWNHALL.COM: They have to be careful about embracing gun control on a national level when there are going to be states and districts that are not going to go for that.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TENNEY: Retaking the House won't be easy for Democrats either though. The latest Fox News poll found a tightening race in voters' candidate preferences with 46 percent saying that they back the Democratic candidate in their district compared to 41 for the Republican. That is a very different picture from October though when Democrats were up by 15 -- Bret.

BAIER: Garrett -- thank you.

Keeping first responders safe during school shootings and other incidents is becoming a focus for law enforcement.

Tonight correspondent Laura Ingle shows us how medical personnel and law enforcement are learning to work together.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LAURA INGLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Trying to save lives while protecting your own.

This is rescue task force training as close to a real-life active shooter incident as it gets.

This drill being run by the National Center for Security and Preparedness is using local EMS and law enforcement agencies in Poughkeepsie, New York. The goal of this training is to bring rapid triage to victims under the protection of armed officers.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We have to stop the killing and we also have to stop the dying.

INGLE: Paramedics learning the language and timed movements of armed entry has been going on nationwide for years.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think I hear gunshots.

INGLE: And recent shootings like Parkland, Florida, some paramedics reported being frustrated when they were held back until a scene is declared safe or a cold zone. A hot zone is when a shooter can directly fire at you. And these teams say a lot of good work can be done in the warm zone when police are present and the danger level has dropped.

SGT. PATRICK BARRY, POUGHKEEPSIE, NEW YORK: That's why we call in a warm zone, you know, it's not totally, let's say, a safe environment. We are still on guard.

CHRIS STRATHAM, NATIONAL CENTER FOR SECURITY AND PREPAREDNESS: I need the police officers focused on the threat and the medics focused on the medicine.

INGLE: Both the Department of Homeland Security and FEMA have issued guidelines for active shooter incidents but there is not a federal mandate on how agencies should work in tandem. With more active shooter situations unfolding across the U.S., some agencies are ramping up their own training so that victims aren't waiting any longer than they have to.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

INGLE: Those who run rescue task force training say these drills will keep evolving as paramedics and law enforcement continue to learn to work together to save lives -- Bret.

BAIER: Laura -- thank you.

Does President Trump have any chance of resurrecting the line item veto? We will look at that next.

But first, the woman behind the Supreme Court case that ended school segregation in the U.S. has died. Linda Brown was a little girl in Topeka when she became the center of the 1954 Brown versus Board of Education landmark decision. Linda Brown -- dead at the age of 76.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: An unusual coalition is putting pressure on Senate Democrats to move ahead with one of President Trump's most high- profile ambassador nominations. It involves longtime U.N. spokesman Rick Grenell who is gay, a Republican, and supports the president. Correspondent Rich Edson looks at the battle from the State Department.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: More than a year into the Trump administration, senior positions at the State Department and high profile ambassador posts remain vacant. Though last week as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell tried to initiate a vote on the president's choice as ambassador to Germany, Rick Grenell, Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley objective.

SEN. JEFF MERKLEY, (D) OREGON: I cannot in good faith support a nominee who has a lengthy track record of tweets attacking both prominent Democratic and prominent Republican women.

EDSON: Grenell has since apologized for tweets and comments he said were intended to be funny and he says he regrets it. In October the Senate Foreign Relations Committee cleared his nomination.

CHRISTIAN WHITON, FORMER STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL: It's a surreal environment up there were the people who profess to care the most about diplomacy, often Democrats, are holding up the most qualified would-be diplomats.

EDSON: Republicans also point out the growing importance of the relationship with Germany. The United States is negotiating with the Germans and other Europeans to change their policies towards Iran. Without an agreement President Trump says he is withdrawing from the Iran nuclear deal.

WHITON: Germany right now is at a very important crossroads. You have Merkel in her final term, a coalition there that involves leftwing elements where we really want to be pushing them away from their worst instincts.

EDSON: If confirmed Grenell would also be the highest profile openly gay official in the Trump administration. He served as the U.S. spokesman at the United Nations during the Bush administration. Though even as Democrats slowed Grenell's confirmation, they point out the administration still has no nominees for other significant State Department positions. Beyond Germany about 40 ambassador jobs remain officially vacant with no pending nominee for South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Egypt, Cuba, the European Union.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EDSON: Secretary of State Rex Tillerson frequently argued with the White House over staffing. He is gone now and it's unclear if his successor, CIA Director Mike Pompeo, if the Senate confirms him, will find better success finding nominees. Bret?

BAIER: Rich Edson at the State Department. Rich, thanks.

President Trump and his advisors are restarting an old conversation about something called the line item veto. The president says it's the only way he can get his economic objectives past a democratic filibuster in the U.S. Senate. Correspondent Doug McKelway tells us tonight it is a road we as a country have been done before.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RONALD REAGAN, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: And tonight I ask you to give me what 43 governors already have, give me a line item veto this year.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Generations of presidents wanted a line item veto. None had it until the Clinton administration when Congress passed the line item veto act of 1996. Clinton used it 82 times before the Supreme Court ruled it unconstitutional two years later. That didn't stop future presidents from wanting it.

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: I think there is not a president out there who wouldn't love to have it.

MCKELWAY: Including President Trump who was clearly frustrated at the Democratic leverage in the omnibus spending bill. While that bill gave him defense spending, it gave them domestic spending, and it gave taxpayers more deficit spending.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I'm calling on Congress to give me a line item veto for all government spending bills.

MCKELWAY: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin repeated the president's call on Sunday, paying no heed to its unconstitutionality.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: I think they should give the president a line item veto.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST: That was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, sir.

MNUCHIN: Again, Congress could pass a rule that allows them to do it.

MCKELWAY: But it would take a constitutional amendment, not just a rule. Congress tried it in 2011 after the high court ruling. It tinkered with a more moderate version of a line item veto that attempted to maintain the balance of power.

BOB CUSACK, "THE HILL" EDITOR IN CHIEF: The president would propose cuts and then Congress would have to approve those cuts. So the president couldn't go in and strike everything that he wanted out.

MCKELWAY: That bill ultimately died in the Senate. So where does that leave President Trump?

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: He wants to fix the budget process, and his message to leaders in Congress of both parties is that if something similar happens again he is much more inclined to veto it.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCKELWAY: So look out for September 30th. That's the date that the current funding bill runs out and the process then begins all over again with a new impediment, the midterm elections just six weeks away. Bret?

BAIER: Doug McKelway up on the Hill. Doug, thanks.

Up next, the panel on expelling Russian diplomats and what retaliation may look like. First, beyond our borders tonight. Sixty-four people, many of them children, are dead tonight following a fire at a shopping mall in Siberia. Officials say four people have been detained. They say it appears the fire alarms did not work and employees did not arrange for evacuation there.

Israeli police meantime again today questioning Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in their ongoing corruption probe. This was the second time Netanyahu had been interviewed about allegations he promoted favorable regulations for the country's telecom giant in exchange for favorable coverage. Netanyahu has denied any wrongdoing.

And Egyptians are voting in an election that President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is virtually guaranteed to end. His only challenger is a little-known politician who joined the race at the last minute to spare the government the embarrassment of a one candidate election after several hopefuls were forced out or arrested.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We will be right back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

THERESA MAY, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: Today 18 countries have announced their intention to expel more than 100 Russian intelligence officers from their countries. This is the largest collective expulsion of Russian intelligence officers in history.

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: The president ordered the expulsion of dozens of Russian intelligence officers and the closure of the Russian consulate in Seattle.

ANATOLY ANTONOV, RUSSIAN AMBASSADOR TO U.S.: What the United States do today is destroying the little that is left from the Russian-American relations.

SHAH: We stand ready to cooperate to build a better relationship with Russia, but this can only happen with a change in the Russian government's behavior.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Big moves today as the U.S. has an expulsion of Russian diplomats. In fact there were 60 Russian diplomats being expelled, described as aggressive intelligence collectors. Forty-eight are now at the Russian embassy, 12 at the U.N. The Russian consulate, as mentioned, in Seattle ordered closed due to a proximity to a submarine base and to Boeing, but there's no specific threat or activity at that facility.

Individuals and their families have been given seven days to leave the U.S. But the U.S. is not alone. Actually 133 Russian diplomats have been expelled from 20 countries. And again, this is in response to the attack on British soil, the poisoning of that U.S. -- of that spy, the British spy, and his daughter.

Let's bring our panel, see where this goes from here, Steve Hayes, editor in chief for "The Weekly Standard," Mollie Hemingway, senior editor at "The Federalist," and David Catanese, senior politics writer for "U.S. News and World Report." Steve, thoughts on today's action?

STEVE HAYES, EDITOR IN CHIEF, "THE WEEKLY STANDARD": I think it's a big deal. This is an impressive move. The fact that the U.S. did it in conjunction not only with the British allies but more than a dozen other countries sends I think a pretty strong message to Russia that this kind of behavior is not going to be tolerated, at least not tolerated for very long without repercussions. So I think it's a good move full stop.

I think it would be better, the president could enhance this move or strengthen it by saying something in his own voice. Just last week he was tweeting that we need better relations with Russia and that people who were calling for him to confront Vladimir Putin on these poisonings or on election meddling in the United States or calling on him not to congratulate Vladimir Putin for a sham election, the president pushed back on that and said that these are people who don't want good relations with Russia, between the United States and Russia, and we are all better off if there are good relations with the United StatesRussia.

I think it's pretty clear Russia has no intention of behaving the way that a civilized country would behave, and the president ought to make it clearer still by saying something directly in his own voice.

BAIER: The kremlin's response, Mollie, is this, "We deeply regret the taken actions. We are to analyze the situation following the decision by number of countries to expel our diplomats. The main analysis will be done by our foreign ministry. After that the president will seek proposals for taking retaliatory steps. A final decision will be made by the head of state. We have said more than once and we say once again, Russia has had nothing to do with this affair whatsoever. Naturally as before we will proceed from the principle of reciprocity," Kremlin spokesman.

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, SENIOR EDITOR, "THE FEDERALIST": Russia made this decision to do this poisoning of a British citizen and his daughter, and they also made the decision to not really respond to the concerns of the world when they raised them. And so now you have this action, more than a dozen, almost two dozen countries expelling diplomats. And it is a strong action, and as Steve says, it does send a message.

It's very difficult when you're doing with nuclear power to do much more than send a message without risking nuclear conflict, but this is something that so serious that more action really is needed. I understand this is the U.K.'s situation and we are in a supportive role even if we expelled more diplomats than they did, but there are other actions that can be taken. Even the intelligence community report last year said anti-fracking movements were something that the Russian government was funding and trying to affect U.S. policy. Doing something policy-wise they can really Russia, or hurt them economically, might be a good way to ramp things up without risking nuclear war.

BAIER: David?

DAVID CATANESE, SENIOR POLITICS WRITER, "U.S. NEWS AND WORLD REPORT": This alleviates some of the critics that have pounded the Trump administration for not acting on Russia, for not being forceful enough. This is the toughest action of the Trump administration has taken to date against Russia.

But I think you also have seen in statements today out of the Senate, particularly from John McCain, that this is an opportunity to do more, that this is an opportunity to move forward with economic sanctions and really hit them hard.

I also think it's going to be striking to watch, what is Putin's next move. I already saw on social media today the Russian government putting out polls saying how should we retaliate? Which consulate of the Americans should be close? And I know there was talk even just last week after the president's call with Putin that there was going to be maybe another meeting between President Trump and Vladimir Putin. That probably puts a chill on that I think at least for the near term.

BAIER: Mollie, I just want to point out these FOX News polls. The first one is the president's job approval, job performance. We have the latest poll up to 45 percent approve, disapprove at 52 percent. And there you can see their previous track there. And the second question, Russia's main goal in election meddling -- chaos, doubt, U.S. democracy, sowing chaos, 57 percent helped Trump win, 21 percent helped Clinton win, five percent.

As you look at these polls and how people are perceiving the actions of the president based on what Steve said, the want for the president to vocalize it a little bit more or a lot more than he is about what's happening on Russia, the actions are different than the voice.

HEMINGWAY: I actually think this kind of shows how silly this entire narrative about the president not being strong against Russia. Objectively speaking he's been stronger than either of his two predecessors against Russian aggression. And it's not just with actions like today's which came at the direction of the president. They are not separate from the president. They were his actions that he recommended taking, and the White House said that.

It's also true that he's been really tough. Even on the Iran deal which is something Russia really wants the U.S. to stay in. Actions in Syria, missile-defense, any number of actions the president has actually been quite tough. And this narrative that he's not been tough, yes, people might want rhetoric that is stronger, but actions count a lot in this matter.

BAIER: I just want to play this one other sound bite. This is Kevin Corke asking the spokesman today about these actions and what they mean.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Does an attack on the soil of the valued ally rise to the level of an active war? Is that the administration's policy?

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: We have been joined at the hip with U.K. on this matter, with the U.K. on this matter. We stand firmly with our ally. Again, I'll classify this as brazen and reckless. I don't want to get ahead of anything the president may or may not announce or declare later on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Where is the line, though, Steve, for an act of war against a country?

HAYES: That's a good question. It's something that comes up in the context of our NATO alliance is. Obviously Raj Shah I think for very understandable reasons didn't want to answer that question directly, certainly not in the affirmative. That might present him some problems.

BAIER: Exactly. Next up, the effort to break the diplomatic logjam in the Senate, and more on that interview with Stormy Daniels.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF MERKLEY, (D) OREGON: I cannot in good faith support a nominee who has a lengthy track record of tweets attacking both prominent Democratic and prominent Republican women. Since his nomination, these tweets have continued, showing a complete disregard for the Senate confirmation process and a disregard for the seriousness of the position to which he is nominated.

SEN. JOHN BARRASSO, (R) WYOMING: Today Democrats deliberately delay in ways that limit us to a couple nominations in a typical week.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: There is one nomination that is pending, and a lot of talk about what's not been filled. But Rick Grenell is the nominee to be the U.S. ambassador to Germany. He is a former U.S. spokesman for -- at the U.N. He's the Trump administration's first openly gay nominee. He cleared the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in October, awaiting a confirmation vote. There are a number of positions that have not been nominated yet, but confirmed, 127, some career holdovers, nominated 18, and vacant without nominees, 44. The ambassador for Germany position is not one of them. Mollie?

HEMINGWAY: I think it is absurd to say that Rick Grenell is facing trouble because of tweets that he made, and I don't take anyone really believes that. It is part of a larger anti-Trump or Democratic strategy to keep Trump from having the people he needs in positions that are key so that bureaucrats can continue to wield the power in those seats. It's really dangerous, though, when you have situations like the ambassador to Germany. This is a very key post, and particularly if the new national security advisor, John Bolton, moves forward in getting out of the Iran deal, you really need someone in Germany. Germany is becoming a much more important place. And it is something where the Trump administration and United States in general could use a strong advocate such as Rick Grenell. So this delay is getting to the point of absurdity.

BAIER: David?

CATANESE: We don't have ambassadors and three dozen countries. So this is the focal point this week because of a "New York Times" story, and I think it also has to do because he would be the highest qualified or highest serving openly gay official in the Trump administration. But we don't have ambassadors in South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Egypt.

And if we are frank about this, a lot of these ambassador posts are rewards to campaign donors. So I think in different countries they matter at different -- it's more significant in some countries that it is other countries. There's a lot of reports out there that staffing can do a lot of these jobs. And remember when Rex Tillerson, I know he is the outgoing secretary of state, he was asked about this a couple weeks ago, and he said, look, this isn't that big of a deal. We can still move forward with policy.

And on foreign policy I think the one thing we have learned out of the Trump administration is there is one man setting it, and that's President Trump. So look, this is a procedural battle, and I think there is also a case to be made that Mitch McConnell, if he wanted to, hold the Senate open all week long, have the debate, have a 30 hours. But if Richard Grenell is very important in Germany, you could also make the case for why don't we have ambassadors and really key Middle East countries like I named, Saudi Arabia, Egypt.

BAIER: Or even Korea.

CATANESE: South Korea.

BAIER: OK, so big interview last night, "60 Minutes," the fallout today. Take a listen to a part of that.

Forget the story. And then he leaned around looked at my daughter and said, a beautiful little girl. It would be a shame if something happened to her mom. And then he was gone.

ANDERSON COOPER: Did you ever see the person again?

DANIELS: No. But if I did, I would know it right away.

DANIELS: No.

COOPER: Why?

DANIELS: Because I was scared.

BAIER: The White House engaging, saying they don't believe that there was a threat made. Michael Cohen, the president's attorney, saying he doesn't believe it. Where does this go from here, Steve?

HAYES: Well, I don't think it goes away. Stormy Daniels is not the most credible accuser that President Trump has had. She's lied specifically about this incident. She has said that she lied about this incident. I think the problem for President Trump is that there are many others who have made similar allegations, whether we are talking about aggressive behavior towards women or we are talking about his folks making thuggish threats on journalists or others who could potentially do him harm.

I don't think the story goes away in part because of the campaign finance aspect of it. Some people are shrugging that off and saying it's not a big deal. Really we're just talking about $130,000. But if you stop and think about what the substance of the case is, what the center of the case is, it's that the president had, or the president's top lawyer allegedly paid $130,000 in hush money shortly before the election because he had an affair with a porn star. That's a big deal. No matter how you look at it, it's a big deal. And I think we'll learn more about how she wants to substantiate her case if she's able to do so in the coming days.

BAIER: We will follow all aspect of it. Panel, thank you very much. When we come back, a new kind of peacemaking.
